bibl.title: Letter from Marie C. Oemler to Emilie Lawrence Reed, March 12, 1928

div1.p: Oemler thanks Emilie Lawrence Reed for the works of Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Marie C. Oemler to Emilie Lawrence Reed, March 12, 1928

opener.dateline:
830 Anderson Street East
Savannah, Ga, March 12, 1928

div1.p:
How truly kind and generous of you it was to write me such a
letter - that my portrait of a man could remind you of Walter Reed! You
can't imagine how it made me feel - at once proud and humble, for Walter
Reed has always seemed to me not only a very great American, but a world
hero, one of those sublime and unselfish souls who are laying the foundation
for the great religion of the future: a Christ-soul. I am sure my man
would have done what yours did, had his scientific bent led him to it. I know
a doctor who, without batting an eyelash, submitted himself to tryouts for
tropical diseases, and studied himself and his own symtoms with perfect scien
tific interest, impersonally. They are like that, aren't they? But how very
fortunate you were, to have loved such a man! Most of us don't know them,
and you haven't reached seventy not to have learned that most women are
afraid of them, never understand them, are frightfully jealous of that scientif
ic side which, thy are sure, is inimical to them and their interests as women
I have known women who have tried, desperately, to deflect them, haven't you?
I myself, madame, am Irish with a big dash of French, and a touch of English
to steady it. But my mother's mother was Irish of the Irish, born in old, old
Clonmel beside the river Suir; and she had the peculiar and beautiful gifts
of the Gaelic Irish, that touch of other-world-ness, which makes them see in
to the spirit side of things. The spiritual world was always very close to
my mother's mother; and with such people the 'invisible things..are clearly
seen, being understood by the things that are made...' For instance, when my
mother's mother met, say, such a soul as Walter Reed, she would watch him
with her clear, large hazel eyes; and she would be very thoughtful; and after
he had gone about his Father's business, and someone else spoke of him, she
might say, quietly “That one possesses his soul.”

Now I happened to have been the best-loved of her grandchildren; and
the closest to her. I have never been so keen-witted; but the spiritual side
of life has ever meant more to me than the material; so you can imagine how
I have never become rich, or a person of many possessions, and how my wor-
ships have ever, necessarily, been laid before slowly built altars of my own
makings. The sense of the Fatherhood of God, the brotherhood of man, has from
my earliest years been very strong in me. I think your man exemplified this
exquisitely; that he lost his mortal sense of life to find his immortal self,
and that he is one of the great Servants, who goes on working, eternally, Some
where Else. 'Greater love hath no man than this, that a man shall lay down his
life for his friends. God has more servants than the thoughtless wish to
believe. Be grateful that yours was one of the great ones.

I could envy you; but I am too grateful for you both. It gave me
a real pleasure to hear from you; it gives me as true a pleasure to pay this
slight tribute of respect to a great soul, who has, since I first learned of
him, remained one of my heroes. You paid the price; butv it was worth it. Most
of us pay - and it wasn't. If ever I happen to come near you, I will come to
see you, out of pure respect. If I cannot do that, take a spiritual wireless
from me. Once, madame, I visited Arcadia.
